subtitle: Greetings from Istanbul. My name is Mehmet Ozdagon
I'm an archaeologist and I would like to welcome to you to a new installment of the
Tiny Lecture series organized by Archaeology Now. My main field work is on the
Neolithic period and I have been working to try to understand where, when,
and how it began and how it dispersed to other parts of the world.
It was three years ago that I was invited to Houston to speak on the new recent findings about the Neolithic in southeastern Turkey
mainly derived by the interesting developments at the enigmatic site of
Göbekli Tepe. So now we call these cultures Göbekli Tepe cultures.
It is found not only on that site, but it's dispersed into
a very large area in the Euphrates and in the upper Tigris basins. So I will
try to make a very brief summary of what we know of that period. However I think
we should first put Göbekli Tepe into a time scale. It is quite early, much earlier
earlier than any other monumental architecture so that's why its quite interesting.
Of course we are in the Neolithic period.
Our conventional understanding of the period (when
I was a student, actually, some decades ago)
was that it was a time when people started cultivating cereals, legumes, and lentils.
They started domesticating animals they developed new technologies, they started
living in permanent houses, they developed villages, and eventually they invented
pottery. With the pottery they started a new way of food preparation,
storing food, serving food, and fermentation.
So now we know that the Neolithic period was not an instantaneous event. It spread
over a very large time scale. There was pottery in the Neolithic.
There was a 3,000 year preceding period of Neolithic clay pottery which we call PPN.
In the earlier phases of clay pottery of the Neolithic, we call the pottery "A" and "B"
are much more fascinating. That's a time of
significance to the culture. What is most challenging about such a
period is that even at its earlier stage, even as they
established large settlements they were still
hunter-gatherers, so they must have been living in a very rich environment so
that they were able to establish numerous big settlements, still by
hunting and gathering. Of course they were
experimenting with seeds in their region, and with animals. So eventually, even though
they were not trying to become farmers, they ended up becoming farmers. They
became farmers during the end of pre-pottery Neolithic period. Once
they become real farmers and when they had herds, there was system collapse and the
farmers were dispersed, they migrated to other regions
bringing with them seeds and animals so it became a global system.
More or less we know the core area of the civilization covers from south Lebanon up to central Anatolia so it's a quite an extensive area. There are different
socio-economic models but they knew each other, they shared information even though they lived in
completely different worlds in most cases. Göbekli Tepi culture is
is restricted to southeast Anatolia, Northern Syria, and Iraq.
There have been numerous excavations. Now, there are more than 28 excavations at the [Göbekli Tepi] site so we know it in quite a bit of detail and also from surface
surveys there's a lot of sites, more than 100 sites of this culture.
Through things found in large-scale excavations we can now see the
social stratification and social systems these sites. We are not only looking at
what they are eating but also how they were living.
It really is a time of new way of living. One of the most challenging
aspects of this culture is that they were innovative. Most traditional cultures are
very conservative. They resist change. But the Göbekli Tepi culture is very
dynamic. It's very open to new innovations. They were experimenting
with architecture. In this period, a hut becomes a house, a house becomes a home and their
architecture developed. They also developed what became
specialized buildings. Houses become temples. In earlier years we
thought temples started much much much later but we now know that there were specialized
buildings. We know there was a lot of them, not only from Göbekli Tepi. This period also has
monumental standing stones. We know they have a special symbolism. Our main
idea of Neolithic symbolism, previously, was that most were female mother goddesses but we now know that there is a
male deity in the temples and also phallic symbolism. They had a
kind of a shamanistic way of understanding nature so they were
depicting pictures of all sorts of living creatures, not only
animals but also insects and birds - everything which is living - not only
edible things. It's a kind of initial symbolism. We were quite
surprised to see was that there was a type of social stratification, although it's not very
clear from burials. There are some burials which adorned with very rich
ornaments.There are some with almost nothing. So clearly there's a social
layering of society. We don't know who's heading society or who was the group at
the top. Was it the clergy or some families? It's
very clear that there's an elite group controlling the
settlement and they are holding power. They dictate taste. There may be signs
competition among elites over who has the best craftsmen. Not only in reference to the
quality of craftsmanship but also in artistic tastes. Within the
whole region you can see that it is a peaceful period and that any
problems that arose came from sharing knowledge and from artistic
competition. They had talented artisans with sophisticated taste and they were
really innovative. All of these figures which come from Göbekli Tepi sites, and
from several sites in this whole area, are very very
innovative, they're all unique. During the last three years
excavations have continued, and especially now in Göbekli Tepi, which is
now being systematically managed. There is
a new shelter and visitor center. To accommodate the new center, they needed to undertake a proper
rescue excavation in order to build foundations. This revealed a lot of domestic
buildings from the earliest phases of settlement. We already knew about
the presence of these buildings, but now we can speak about a much larger settlement
than we knew. Now we have much more better documentation of the site. Even in regard to the
temples, we have more detailed documentation. Our picture
of Göbekli Tepi, the site, is changing dramatically. Also, as they excavate
more of the surrounding area, there are new standing
stones and new artistic depictions. During the last three years also they've been doing new
excavations. One of the most fascinating is Boncuklu Tarla in the eastern part
of the region about 200 kilometres east of Göbekli Tepi in the Tigris basin. This site
also starts with round buildings, PPNA, and several houses. Its an enormous big site and it
also continues to develop with a rectangular phase of buildings, with cult buildings. There are standing stones which is like
Göbekli Tepe, only the stones are
smaller. There is the same mentality.
In my lecture many years ago in Houston
I had presented a lot of prestige objects about the pre-pottery Neolithic
culture that were all very unique objects. But as more excavations
continue, their numbers are increasing. Some of the most
fascinating ones are these stone plaques with stone inlays. You
should consider that we are still in the pre-pottery Neolithic period so the tools
they have are either flint or obsidian. They could really make an inlay
of pebbles! This object is a
kind of fantasy. It's a pebble insert or inlay with pebbles or beads coming from
other regions and made into a bead It is, I think, quite difficult.
The number of prestige objects and the typology of objects found
is also increasing. Every site, we find, is producing new ones. For example, a smiling snake
is just a fantasy but it's quite unique.
To make this long story short I think the most important thing about
the Neolithic period of this region is its innovation and sharing of knowledge. They are
competing with each other and they are developing new things. The
moment they develop something, it spreads out, very peacefully. Nobody's monopolizing the
culture. They are really sharing sources. Their main assets must have been who had knowledge and artisans:
who has the best craftsmen, who has the best building, who has the best
architect. Everybody would have known about developments. But when the system collapsed,
most of the farmers left but the
systems remained in the region and later it gave birth to more complex
societies. Surplus economies developed that lead to the emergence of towns and states,
kingdoms, empires, and the modalities of living until the Industrial Revolution.
The Neolithic period is a very innovative period, a very important period for
understanding what was happening in the past. With every new excavation, our
ideas are getting more and more challenged. There's a lot
we have to learn and our way of looking at the Neolithic period is steadily changing.
I am very thankful for your patience and for giving us the opportunity to talk with
you today.
